findings.message: [SQL Injection Detection] Potential SQL injection: f-string interpolation in SQL query
findings.detail:
Use parameterized queries instead:
✅ GOOD: cursor.execute('SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = ?', (user_id,))
✅ GOOD: cursor.execute('SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = :id', {'id': user_id})
❌ BAD: f'SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = {user_id}'
findings.code: query = f"SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = {user_id}"

findings.detail: user_id is interpolated directly into the SQL query string using an f-string. An attacker can pass arbitrary SQL (e.g., '1; DROP TABLE users--') to execute unintended commands. This violates the precondition that query parameters must be sanitized before reaching the database engine. Use parameterized queries (db.execute('SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = ?', (user_id,))) instead.
findings.code: query = f"SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = {user_id}"

findings.message: No postcondition guarantee on return value
findings.detail: db.execute() may return None, an empty result set, a cursor object, or raise an exception (connection error, syntax error, timeout). The caller has no contract about what to expect. If the caller assumes a non-None iterable, a NoneType or cursor-without-results will propagate as a downstream AttributeError or TypeError.

db.execute() can raise OperationalError, ProgrammingError, InterfaceError, or other database exceptions. Without a try/except, any database failure propagates an uncontrolled exception to the caller, potentially leaking internal schema details in stack traces (information disclosure).

debt_items.message: [SQL Injection Detection] Potential SQL injection: f-string interpolation in SQL query
No postcondition guarantee on return value
